title: 103_hr1205
content:
The "District of Columbia Retrocession Act of 1993" allows for the retrocession of the District of Columbia to Maryland, with Congress retaining legislative authority over the National Capital Service Area. SEC. 3. EFFECT ON JUDICIAL PROCEEDINGS IN DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.

No ongoing court cases in the District of Columbia will be affected by this Act. They will be transferred to and continue in the appropriate courts of the State of Maryland.

(b) Appeals.--Orders or decisions from the District of Columbia will be treated as such from the State of Maryland for appeal purposes.

SEC. 4. NATIONAL CAPITAL SERVICE AREA. The National Capital Service Area includes key federal monuments and buildings such as the White House, Capitol Building, and Supreme Court Building. It is defined by specific boundaries starting from the Virginia-District of Columbia boundary to the Kennedy Center and E Street Expressway. The National Capital Service Area boundaries extend from the Virginia-District of Columbia boundary to the E Street Expressway, then follows a specific route through various streets including E Street Northwest, Nineteenth Street Northwest, F Street Northwest, Eighteenth Street Northwest, Constitution Avenue Northwest, Seventeenth Street Northwest, H Street Northwest, Madison Place Northwest, Pennsylvania Avenue Northwest, and Fifteenth Street Northwest. The curr_chunk describes a route starting from Pennsylvania Avenue Northwest to Second Street Northwest, following various streets like Fifteenth Street Northwest, Tenth Street Northwest, E Street Northwest, Ninth Street Northwest, John Marshall Place Northwest, C Street Northwest, Third Street Northwest, and D Street Northwest. The route continues east on D Street Northwest to Second Street Northwest, then south on Second Street Northwest to Constitution Avenue Northwest and Louisiana Avenue Northwest. It then goes northeast on Louisiana Avenue Northwest to North Capitol Street, north on North Capitol Street to Massachusetts Avenue Northwest, southeast on Massachusetts Avenue Northwest to Union Square, following Union Square to F Street Northeast, east on F Street Northeast to Second Street Northeast, south on Second Street Northeast to D Street Northeast, west on D Street Northeast to First Street Northeast, south on First Street Northeast to C Street Northeast, and finally east on C Street Northeast to Third Street. The route continues east on C Street Northeast to Third Street Northeast, then south on Third Street Northeast to Maryland Avenue Northeast, west on Maryland Avenue Northeast to Constitution Avenue Northeast, west on Constitution Avenue Northeast to First Street Northeast, south on First Street Northeast to Maryland Avenue Northeast, north and east on Maryland Avenue to Second Street Northeast, south on Second Street Northeast to East Capitol Street, east on East Capitol Street to Third Street Northeast, south on Third Street Northeast to Independence Avenue Southeast, and finally west on Independence Avenue Southeast to Second Street Southeast. The route then continues south on Second Street Southeast to C Street Southeast, west on C Street Southeast to New Jersey Avenue Southeast, south on New Jersey Avenue Southeast to D Street Southeast, west on D Street Southeast to Washington Avenue Southwest, north and west on Washington Avenue Southwest to the intersection of Independence Avenue Southwest and Second Street Southwest, south on Second Street Southwest to Virginia Avenue Southwest, west on Virginia Avenue to Third Street Southwest, north on Third Street Southwest to C Street Southwest, and finally west on C Street Southwest to Sixth Street Southwest. The route then continues west on C Street Southwest to Sixth Street Southwest, south on Sixth Street Southwest to E Street Southwest, west on E Street Southwest to Seventh Street Southwest, north on Seventh Street Southwest to Maryland Avenue Southwest, west on Maryland Avenue Southwest to Ninth Street Southwest, north on Ninth Street Southwest to Independence Avenue Southwest, west on Independence Avenue Southwest to Twelfth Street Southwest, south on Twelfth Street Southwest to D Street Southwest, west on D Street Southwest to Fourteenth Street Southwest, south on Fourteenth Street Southwest to the middle of the Washington Channel, and then generally south and east along the midchannel. The route continues along the Washington Channel, following the midchannel, then east to the side of the channel, south and east along the side at the mean high water mark to the confluence with the Anacostia River, and further south and west along the shore to the confluence of the Anacostia and Potomac Rivers. The National Capital Service Area includes the Anacostia River, Potomac River, District of Columbia boundary, Virginia-District of Columbia boundary, streets, sidewalks, and Federal real property. The National Capital Service Area includes various Federal properties such as the Department of Housing and Urban Development Building, Department of Energy Building, Fort Lesley McNair, Washington Navy Yard, Anacostia Naval Annex, United States Naval Station, Bolling Air Force Base, and Naval Research Laboratory. It does not include Rock Creek Park, Anacostia Park east of the Eleventh Street Bridge, or any territory outside the District of Columbia before the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Transition provisions for the House of Representatives. Temporary Increase in Apportionment: Until the first reapportionment after this Act, the Delegate from DC will serve as a member of the House from Maryland, Maryland will have an additional Representative, not counted against the total number of members. The temporary increase in House of Representatives membership will not change the permanent membership or reapportionment basis. Laws providing for a Delegate from DC are repealed, restoring previous provisions. SEC. 6. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS: Existing laws and regulations will not be automatically changed by this Act unless specified or if they conflict with it.

SEC. 7. PROCLAMATION REGARDING RETROCESSION BY MARYLAND: Once Maryland accepts retrocession, the President will announce the return of the ceded territory.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE: The Act will come into effect on a specified date. The Act and its amendments will take effect when the President issues a proclamation under section 7 or upon the ratification of an amendment repealing the twenty-third article of the Constitution.
